passing through Catillon . The roads are very muddy. We are billetedin Priches. The people here also were robbed of everything of value by the Bosches. Madam's husband has been a prisoner for over 4 years. The Bosches forced her to sell her cows at their price in German paper money on which they put an inflated value reckoning the Mark = 15d. They controlled all food here & forced the French farmers to deliver their milk at central Laiteries at their price. Madam here once kept about 1½ gallons for her household, was caught by the Controller, imprisoned & fined 400 Marks. All eggs had to be delivered to the officers at their own price. Poultry was stolen all the time.

Raining - Took my company out during a break to salvage vegetables as our rations are rather short lately. of 13th,14th,15th,16th, Bns. & 4th. Field Engineers in company with Brigade M.O. & Q.M.

Entry.19: Rode to Fourmiesand Wyhgnies with Dick Swinburne - met the Americans we had previously met (Mechanic Roy Lindsay) coming to visit me in his car. He had his officer with him. I invited them to afternoon tea on Sunday (8th).
Entry.20:
Lectured to Bn. on Historical Connection between England & France.

Led Debate - 13th versus 15th Bn. "That Australia should have Unification - A keen debate- 15th Bn won.



7th
"A" Coy officers entertained the C.O. Major Allen & Capt McKillop at Mess & spent a very pleasant evening.
Entry.22: - Church Parade at Pierrot Theatre.Spoke to company about Xmas dinner preparations. This afternoon two Americans attachedas Mechanics to a French Division now stationed at Fourmiesvisited me. We entertained ourselves with Gramaphone & watching Guard mounting, before afternoon tea, after which we yarned.
Entry.23:
Lectured to Bn. on Historical Convention between England & France dealing especially with Jeanne d'Arc. Led debate as Premier - 13th Bn. v 15th Bn. at YMCA on Unification of Australia. - 15th won.

10th
Bn. Parade in morning - Football match in afternoon. I have a sore neck. There are several cases in the Brigade like it. Neck in rash & itchy.
Entry.24: Posted parcel to Jess containing two German gas masks - registered it for 4fr 90c. Off parade with sore neck.
Entry.25: Off parade with sore neck & face - a rash - itchy & blotchy. Attended Company Commanders' meeting at Hqrs. Mess. Discussed Xmas Dinner for the troops. Borrowed two books from the Padre - Major Duniford M.C. - "Clementina" by Mason & "Jesus Christ & the Social Question" by F.G. Peabody - Commenced reading "Clementina" - very interesting & well written. Wrote Mrs Alexander (Redhill), Miss Ina Cowley & George.
Entry.26:
Still off parade - Bn. preparing to move forward to Florennestomorrow - a 3 day march. Received large Xmas Cake from Jess and the scamps, also

three pairs of beautiful socks. Socks are plentiful now. Everyone has 3 pairs - I have 9 pairs. I finished reading "Clementina" & commenced "Jesus Christ & Social Question". Wrote to Jess - Had the cake for afternoon tea - A drizzly day & windy.
Entry.27:
We commenced our march to Florennespassing from Sainsthrough Ramousiesto Sivry. I rode on horse ambulance on account of my face. We crossed into Belgium about midday. The people here are scrupulously clean & their houses outside & inside shine. We have received a most cordial welcome. These Belgians are totally different to the 
Walloons
 Flemings in Flanders in hospitality, cleanliness, speech & modes of living.

Germans were E. & Brit. W. of Sivrywhen armistice commenced. A few shots were fired across the town.

They regard the "Flamands" with very little love - calling them Germans rather than Belgians. "A 
Walloon
 Flamand comes with a prayer book in one hand and a knife in the other" said a madame to me.

I have a very comfortable clean bed and have enjoyed a long conversation with M. Mme. & Mmlle. They speak better French than the French people we have met themselves.
Entry.28:
Marched from Sivryto Silenrieux- roads muddy & sloppy. Silenrieux is a picturesque village. A train is now running to Brusselles daily. My billet was with M & Mme Brusseret a fine couple of a superior class & very wealthy before the war. He was a grain dealer. The Germans burnt his home

after looting it. They shot several civilians here"for no reason at all" as my friends told me. At SivryI learned from several sources that the Germans had shot some children including a little girlwho offered a "scone" to an English prisoner. They shot her on the spot.

Remark by Madame, at Sivry -

"A Walloon woman's greatest delight is in being clean & industrious in her home, a French woman's greatest delight is to be stylish in the streets."

16
Marched to Florennes. It rained for most of the journey. The 14th & 15th Bns stayed at Phillipville . Along the track were a great many German motor lorries & transport gear. Here we have comfortable billets but the men are somewhat cramped for space

- quite different to our very large billets at Sains. There is Electric Light everywhere, quite free apparently, as no house has a meter. The men have it in their billets. I rode on horse ambulance today on account of my sore face. I have a comfortable clean room with clean sheets - the third time in my three nights in Belgium. The people are very courteous & desirous of doing all they can for us. Madame here has 2 children of her own and two nieces from Flanders who are living with her to learn French. She is a 
Walloon
 Flamand but dislikes the 
Walloons
 Flamands of Flanders - from Ghent, Bruges, Ypres - and said the people here were afraid of the 
Walloons
 Flamands working in the district. The only union between the two races in Belgium is the one of Religion



both races being R.C.

17
Remained in bed until 11am as my face is still ugly & sore. Asked Lt McRae to look after the Company's Xmas Dinner arrangements.

The Belgians in the three places I have been in tell me that they were better treated than the French or English by the Germans, that the Germans hated the English above all other nations, & that they had repeatedly spoken of the wonderful colonial troops of England. At Sivry they paid the Belgian prisoners and fed them but starved the French & English. The latter were often seen eating raw potatoes or turnips in the field.

18 - 23rd
Lectured to Bn. two lectures "Sea Power in British History".

Padre Finnigan (4th. M.G.Bn.) lectured twice - Subjects - "With the Light Horse in Sinai", "Egypt".

22nd
Rode with Merifield into Bois de MiniÃ¨res. Road sloppy & boggy - visited St Aubain & Morialme. -

23rd
Completed M.S. of "Two Blues" our Bn. Journal.

25th Decr.
My Coy & Officers all had Xmas Dinner together in Jesuit College Hall at Florennes.

Dinner arranged by Lt McRae - Each man put in 5fr. Officers 30fr. Splendid Success - PiÃ¨ce de Resistance - Roast Goose.

1am

31st
Visited Bde Hqrs to see New Year In. They then, with 16th Bn. visited our Mess & remained until 4 am, singing, drinking, dancing together.

1st 1.19
Bn. Sports. I acted as Starter. I won 1 mile Bn. Walking Champ. - Prize valued 15 francs.Very successful sports.

5th
 "A" Coy. had a musical evening together in school room- Cocoa, Cake, Biscuits, Chocolates, Beer.

5th
Visited Charleroiby motorbus. A large industrial centre & canal port. Up-to-date city with electric trams & decent buildings & streets - Lt Merifield accompanied me.

14th
Published "Two Blues" - No 7 Issue - Evacuated to C.C.S. Charleroi with Dermatitis of Chin, caused by too close shaving & using infected water or something of the sort -most probably infected water at Sainsdu Nord.

15th
In C.C.S. at Charleroi. A visitor (Belgian) kept us most interested this afternoon for about

three hours with stories about Belgians & Germans. He is a Walloon & a splendid class - very young looking for his age (36), fair & well educated.

Good Idea
 - Educational Classes in all Shearing Sheds and isolated mines similar to those now in operation in the Military.

18th
In No 25 Gen. Hospital - South of Boulogne. Arrived at No 14 Gen Hospital last night
Entry.30:
after being in train 44 hours - a frightfully slow journey.

My face feels quite well but will not be quite right for shaving for a fortnight.

This hospital is staffed by Australian sisters.

Read at 20 C.C.S. at Charleroi Utopia ( More) and "Blue Lagoon" (Stacpoole), The Temptress (Oppenheim). Read at 14 General Hospital during last night & today "The Second Book

of Artemis " and "A Man's Man" by Ian Hay.

Read this evening here "Romance of Blithedale" (Nat Hawthorne).
Entry.31:
Wrote Col Allen C.O. 13th bn. - examined by Doc. - marked Dermititis - 
Treatment
 - Drink Soda Bicarb etc. before meals -Ichthyol ointment on back & Calamine Liniment on face. Wrote Jess, parents & bro. George. 
Read
Enjoyed two long walks along the beach which is here very fine- quite long & very wide & hard when the tide is out. The sand dunes are very interesting being much cut about by wind & water, but held together by long grass. A bright sunny day and quite warm.

Marked for evacuation to England.

20th.
Evacuated from No 25 G.H. to England to 3rd London General Hosp. Wandsworth. Left Hardelot (No 25) five miles S. of Boulogne at 11.30 - sailed from Boulogne at 1.20. Had a good lunch before sailing - Very rough crossing made me seasick. Entered Dover about 3.10 - Dover Harbour packed with destroyers, mine sweepers submarines and camouflaged vessels of all kinds.

Hospital train to London a splendid train - detrained at Kennington & driven (with Lt Backhouse 1st Bn. AIF) to
Entry.32: L.G.H. in a beautiful car. - 4 seater - Sent to Ward C10.
Entry.33:
Face fomented on account of several swelling glands & forehead rubbed with Calamine Liniment. Spent a lazy day

read several magazine articles "Frenzied Fiction" (by Stephen Leacock) an amusing clever selection of stories. Commenced reading "Red Hand of Ulster" by Birmingham. Read scrapily through chapters of Mahan's Sea Power & its Influence on History. Visited by Aust. Red Cross Rep. to give me everything I wanted.
Entry.34: Borrowed Garibaldi's "Defence of the Roman Republic" from the Educational Staff at Hospital. Read some of it, several magazines & an Australian Bulletin & a Hospital publication.
Entry.35:
- Sunday
Still in hospital. My face has been worse during the week - cracked very much, but is much better today. Weather mild & cloudy.
Entry.36: Examined by Dr Cormack, a skin specialist - diagnosis Dermatitis - nothing serious.
Entry.37: Finished reading Trevelyan's "Garibaldi's Defence of the Roman Repc." most interesting & well written.
Entry.38: Visited City - Horseferry Road to purchase breeches - walked through Victoria St, Trafalgar Square, Strand, Chancery Lane. Called at Binghams Hotel.
Entry.39: Went St Martin's Theatre with Lt Scott (Canadian). Saw "When Knights Were Bold". Afternoon tea near Strand at Lyons. Snowing.-
Entry.40:
2nd
Stayed in Ward & read & played cards.







Read "Garibaldi's Making of Italy" by Trevelyan - a very fine work.

Read Mason's "Four Feathers" a well written interesting novel.

Entry.48:

Rode in 'Bus from Clapham Junction to Hyde Park, walked from Hyde Park Corner to Marble Arch, thence along Oxford St. to Tottenham Court Road Tube, thence bused to Mansion House & walked to Fleet St. Visited show of Models of aeroplanes, war vessels, shells & trenches in OxfordSt.

10th

& other 4th Brigade officers. Lunched at Australian Officers Club, 138 Picadilly with Russell Jones & King

Arrived here at 37 Holland Park - a very comfortable home.

Visited A.I.F. Clothing Store for ties & Handkerchiefs.

Visited Wandsworth Hospital (3rd L.G.H.) to pick up some extra Kit I had left behind.

Met Joe Westwood & Russell Jones of 13th. Bn. & had tea with them.
Entry.51:
Visited Lambeth Palace with Overseas Soldier Teachers. Was very interested in its wonderful library, old crypt & architecture. We were entertained there at afternoon tea - a very good one - by Archbishop & Mrs. Davidson. After this another officer &

myself visited House of Lords & heard debate on Agricultural Boards by Lords Lincolnshire & Ernle. In the evening went to Theatre Apollo "Soldier Boy" a kind of musical melodrama. 
Lily
 Dorothy Brunton of Sydney takes a leading part in it quite well.

13th
Met Capt Bone of 13th. just down from his College at Manchester where he is studying Industry & Commerce. He is walking about quite well with his two artificial feet.

Visited Horseferry Road to inquire re Education Scheme.

Met two Canadian officers I had been with in Hospital - 3rd. London General - & had tea with them at Lyons Popular CafÃ©, Picadilly . Went to Queens Theatre & saw "Luck of the Navy" a good instructional play & well acted. During the

afternoon I spent half an hour in Westminister Abbey (Poets' Corner).

Entry 25th Feb.

Readmitted today to 3rd L.G.H. with 14 boils on forehead & neck - very painful.

At 37 Holland Park (6th. A.A.H.) I had a very comfortable & pleasant time - visited several theatres on passes.

24th. Feb.
Visited 3rd. L.G.H. to see Skin Specialist Dr. Pringle. Advised to return to Hospital for further treatment.

During the afternoon I visited House of Commons on a Pass obtained from Australia House & heard two good speeches on the Coal Situation. The miners have threatened to strike 
by
 on March 15th unless their demands are granted. Lloyd George, Prime Minister wishes them to await result of a Statutory Inquiry 
to which
 the report

of which is to be published before 31st. March. Saw Lloyd George.

Played a good deal of Bridge at Holland Park.

Read "Savrola" by Winston Churchill - well written & interesting.

25th
Attended History Lecture on Italy in 19th Century - A very ordinary lecture.

Entry 1st. March
A bright warm day - Read, during the week, "Villa Rose" by A.E.W. Mason - adventurous & interesting. Read "Economics for General Reader" H. Clay. Visited by Capt. Les Cleland, Lt Dwyer. Visited Lt Brierley in hospital with Influenza.

2nd. March
Read History of Europe 1814-1914 by G Burren-Smith . A bright warm day.

Entry
Entry.52:
Still in 3rd L.G.H. Have had injection CorossalManganese for my boils. They are getting better.

Have had a Temperature & high pulse after each injection & have had to remainin bed for 3 days each time.

Wrote Joy today.

Concert this evening

11th
Visited Holland Park Aust. Officers' Hospital to get washing I left behind. Gave 5/- to a hard up digger.

Have during the week read "The Virginian" (Owen Wister) for
Entry.53:
time,"Edward Barry" by Louis Beeke & "The Voice of the City" by O'Henry.

Entry.54:
Have finished reading "A Roman Singer" by Marion Crawford - not very interesting, "Scenesof Clerical Life" by George Eliott - quite 
amusing
 interesting & in parts very amusing. Finished and noted "Utopia".
Entry.55: Examined by Specialist on Skin - Several obstinate little boils on neck - ordered
Entry.57: Had 4th injection of Corossal Manganese. High Temperature & pulse - bed early.
Entry.59:
At Copsley Outwood Redhill, Surrey at Mrs. Dyce-Alexander's. She is a wonderfully generous & active old lady - a thorough Christian if ever there was one. I was met at Redhill Station & motored to Copsley - about 6 miles.

Reading "Dombey & Son".
Entry.60: Breakfast in bed - a delightful tray - porridge, rich milk, brown sugar, - egg & bacon, toast & dairy butter, tea. Everything arranged with great daintiness - justfor one. Had a long read of Newspapers, magazines & Dombey & Son. After dinner we had Parlor Evening Games.
Entry.61: Attended Church at Outwood in morning. Visited an old astronomer - Mr Moore & had a look at Sun & Sunspots & Spectrum through his telescope. Went for a walk with other officers. There are 8 officers staying here.
Entry.62:
Journeyed to London from Horley with Mrs. Alexander & her niece Miss Dyce

Sharp. Lunched at Mrs. A's club in Stratford Place - off Oxford St. - took 'bus to Wandsworth to hospital to see Specialist Dr. Pringle. He thinks I am much improved - ordered ½ pastille of Xray to be applied to my neck.

Read "Dombey & Sons".
Entry.63: Had Xray applied to my neck - each side for 9 minutes - walked to Clapham Junction & caught train to Redhill where Mrs. A & car were waiting for me.
Entry.64:
Mrs. A arranged a motor tour with her two cars for 7 officers & herself to 
Tunbridge Wells
 - a well known spa of England. We took plenty of lunch & tea with us. Hot tea was ready for us at the Hollands, a beautiful Country Home near Tunbridge Wells. We were shown thro the grounds & house & lunched in the Hot House among

ferns & flowers. We had a stroll through "Ye Pantiles" - a picturesque promenade - at Tunbridge Wells - visited Toad Rocks & had afternoon at Mrs. Campbell's. Mrs. C. is a widow of Archdeacon Campbell's & once lived in Bathurst, Australia.

From Tunbridge Wells we motored through very pretty country to Penshurst House - the seat of Lord Hardinge of India fame. The village is quite quaint & picturesque - its old butcher's shop dating from 1610. The House contains one of the finest examples of old dining room - with its oak benches & tables & fireplace in centre of floor.
Entry.65: Motored to Redhill to meet another Australian officer - Lt Donaldson (A.F.C.) - Had two long walks.
Entry.66:
Snowed heavily last night but today is quite sunshiny

& the snow on the trees & ground makes a very pretty sight.
Entry.67: At church at Outwood - A Jew clergyman preached for funds to Christianize the Jews of Palestine & Mesopotamia.
Entry.68: Returned to London to see Dr Pringle - skin specialist.Visited A.I.F. Hqrs to arrange to study Industrial Education while awaiting my boat. Visited R.C. Cathedral- Westminister - A fine large building which will be beautiful when finished inside. Ordered injection of 2cc. CorossalManganese by Dr. My hip issore with it.
Entry.69: Passed an achy & restless night. Remained in ward near the fire. Visited by brother George.
Entry.70: Took a short walk to Clapham Junction.
Entry.71:
Visited A.I.F. Hqrs re arranging visits to Industrial Educational

centres while waiting for a boat. Nothing definite here as the Chief Med. Officer has to certify I am able. Visited Australian Hospital, Holland Park to collect my Journal box, walking stick, field glasses & prismaticcompass.

Came down to Outwood - Mrs A met me at Redhill Station.
Entry.72: Returned to London from Copsley. Visited British Museum. Visited Dr. Pringle - Skin Specialist. This evening I trained to Richmond & enjoyed a long walk along Thames, had dinner there & rode back in top of 'bus.
Entry.73:
Boarded at Horseferry Road & marked for return to Australia by Hospital Ship.

Visited National Gallery.
Entry.74: Visited Horseferry Road & drew £12, put my paybook in to be audited. Had afternoon tea at Lyons Strand Corner House with Lt Bradley V.C. of 16th. Bn. & then caught trainfrom Victoria to Redhill - met by Mrs. Alexander & motored to Copsley.
Entry.75: Taken with 3 other Australian officers by Mrs. A for a motor tour through Redhill, Reigate, Dorking & almost to Guildford. Had tea at White Horse Hotel in Dorking. A perfectly delightful trip through most picturesque & interesting parts of Surrey.
Entry.77: Bn) & Lt Sides (4th Div Pioneers) - visited aquarium at Brighton, also walked along the Sea Front & Pier.
Entry.78:
I returned to London - Drew £12 & met Roy Withers. Took him to lunch at Victoria Station.

During afternoon I visited Regents Park & the Zoo. Met George, strode the streets of West End, finally putting up at Kenilworth Hotel.

Sunday - At Kenilworth Hotel
Took a walk during the morning along Holburn, Kingsway, Strand, Fleet Street, visited St Paul's Cathedral & then had dinner at "Ye Old Cheshire Cheese" Hotel in Fleet St. This is a famous old inn where Dr. Johnson dined regularly, it being then quite old. The present rooms date from about 1680. The chief dishes are "Ye Old Cheshire Pudding" of beef, kidney & mushrooms & pancakes. I met my brother George at Picadilly Circus at 2.15 pm & together we visited the Spears at Crouch End. Had afternoon tea there & then visited their brother Dr. Spears. I returned to hospital in the evening.
Entry.79:
Saw Dr Pringle, my doctor at hospital at 3 pm then applied for leave

until Tuesday 22ndApril. I had to have leave endorsed by Australian Hqrs. From Horseferry Rd. I taxi'd to Euston & took a ticket to Blaenau Festinog. Arrived at Chester at midnight & put up at Queen's Hotel.
Entry.80:
Took tramride through Chester to Saltney & back. Then walked the quaint old streets, making small purchases & visiting the following places - Bishop Lloyds Palace, Cathedral and

Left Chester at 3 pm & after chat with a gentleman on train I decided to stay at Bettws-y-Coed, putting up at Waterloo Hotel.
Entry.81:
During the evening I took two brisk walks along the river. - Wrote Jess.

16th
Visited Swallow Falls & Miners' Bridge. Swallow Falls

were delightfully pretty especially after the heavy rain.

After lunch, I settled my account of 22/6 for bed & 3 meals & tips & took trinfor Carnarvon. Arriving at Carnarvon I inspected the Castle in company with an American Padre. It is a delightful old castle & from the towers one gets a magnificent view of Snowdon & surrounding peaks.

Put up at Prince of Wales Hotel.

17th
Returned to Chester - walked round the old town on the wall. Spent 3 hours here & then caught train to Liverpool. Put up at Compton Hotel, Church St. Liverpool.

18 Good Friday
After breakfast I walked through the main streets & along the wharves of the Mersey. Spent afternoon at New Brighton - riverside summer resort

Entry.83:
Walked for 2 hours through business portions of Liverpool. Saw tremendous numbers of very filthy women & children & many stunted or physically defective people.

Left Liverpool at 4 pm for Manchester arriving there 40 minutes later. Put up at Midland Hotel & after dinner went for a walk & was surprised to meet Capt Bone of 13th Bn. We had coffee & lemonade together.
Entry.84:
(Easter)
Slept in until 10 am. Went to lunch with Capt.

Bone at his boarding house. The day was fine & bright & we enjoyed a tramride out to Prestwick. I then took Capt. Bone to afternoon tea & dinner at my hotel. Bought a pair of breeches from Capt. B for 30/-.
Entry.85: Settled Hotel bill - £1.18/-. Room for 2 nights - 16/-. 3 ordinary dinners
Entry.86:
- Tea 2/-.

Caught train for Rugby & then came on to Leamington Spa. Booked up at Crown Hotel, walked about for an hour & then rode on top of tram to Warwick & back.
Entry.87:
Visited Kenilworth Castle. Had a most interesting guide to show me around the ruins.

Returned to Leamington for lunch

then trained to Stratford-on-Avon for the Shakesperian Festival. Could not get hotel room here, but was fortunate enough to get a decent room in a private house for two nights.

Walked around the town looking at old buildings e.g. Tudor House, Harvard, Judith Shakespeare's home & visited the Grammar School at which Shak. was a scholar. I then went to the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre and thoroughly enjoyed "As You Like It" by the Nigel Playfair Company, in quite a unique setting.
Entry.88:
- Wednesday
Joined in Shakespeare's Procession from his birthplace to his tomb. About 1500-2000 took part in this, all carrying flowers mentioned by Shakespeare. I carried buttercups and primroses which I placed, with the thousand other

floral tributes on Shakespeare's grave. Many Americans in uniform were here. After the procession in company with a Canadian padre I inspected the Church. Then with a New Zealand Y.M.C.A. manager I visited Shak's birthplace & bought several little souvenirs.

In the afternoon, with this N.Zealander & two of his lady friends I visited Ann Hathaway's Cottage. Had tea near by & then returned to town to have another walk around. In the evening I accompanied the New Zealander & his lady friend to the Theatre to see parts of "Coriolanus" and "Merry Wives of Windsor" played by Sir F. Benson, Lady Benson & Genevieve Ward.
Entry.89:
Left Stratford on Avon for Oxford. Visited here Bodleian Library & Reading Room. From the Reading Room one gets a wonderful view of the Churches, Colleges

town, & country round Oxford. Visited Church of St Katherine & Cathedral as well as some college Halls & galleries, the hall & gallery of Christ College being specially fine. Walked along the river & watched two College crews training in rowing. Returned to London to hospital.
Entry.90:
Anzac Day
I went into London early to see the Australians march through London. It was a splendid and an inspiring sight - 5000 men representing all arms of AIF - 20 aeroplanes flew over London as the escort & attracted great attention as they performed wonderful feats - looping & rolling in every way. Received 4 letters from Jess & one from Mother.
Entry.91: Very tired & resting in ward - cabled to Jess arriving midwinter.
Entry.92:
Sunday
After two hours' bright sunshine in the morning it snowed heavily all day & night. Stayed in

hospital & played Bridge - lost 2/-.
Entry.93: Went into City to Australian Hqrs - learned that I was to sail by "Karoola" hospital boat on
Entry.94:
Drew 30 days' advance pay from 6thMay - £23.

Bought large suit case for £3/10/-. Left King's Cross for Cambridge. Snow is lying deep all over the country between London & Cambridge. Stayed at Gt Northern Hotel.

29th
With a Naval Air Officer, Capt Rhys Soar visited colleges, chapel, halls and The Backs. Bought two books - Napoleon (Tegg) & Edward I.

Left Cambridge 4.10pm. Trained to Ely & then to Lincoln. At Saracen's Head Hotel.

30th
Visited Lincoln Cathedral & Castle & walked through the streets. Lincoln Cathedral externally seems to me the finest I have seen, but all cathedrals are finest in their own way. The large tower is certainly the grandest I have seen. The view from the Castle Tower is very fine & one can see for many miles. Lincoln Cathedral & Castle are situated much higher than the town.

Arrived at 
Doncaster
 at 2 p.m. & spent two & a half hours there. Visited fine large church - well worth visiting & walked about the streets. An uninteresting town - an important railway junction & manufacturing town. Noted for Racecourse. Left Doncaster at 4.30 for Darlington. A fine day.

Arrived at 79 North Road, Darlington at 7.15 & took my cousin Ina to Picture Show.

1st
Stayed in Darlington. Went to Theatre in evening with cousin.

2nd
Returned to London to Kings Cross - Left my Riding crop in train,returned to hospital.
Entry.96: At Copsley - Church with Mrs. Alexr. & communion. Spent a very pleasant day here.
Entry.97:
Returned to London with Mr. Maw FRAS. Purchased razor & a few small things. Wired to George to meet me at Picadilly at 7- also to Aunt Rose to see me at Devonport before I sailed. Met George at 7 & together we visited Misses Spear, 5 Crouch Hall Road, Crouch End.

Spent a very pleasant evening. Reached hospital at 11.15.
Entry.98:
Left hospital by Ambulance

for hospital train at Paddington. Went to Southampton instead of Devonport. Embarked on hospitalship "Karoola". Lay to near Southampton all night.

7th-14th
Splendid voyage & very little seasickness aboard. The food is splendid all round. Saw Southern Cross on
Entry.99: low down on our track. Two men have been Buried at sea - one on
Entry.100:
the second today.

Mail closed today. It is to go from Sierra Leone tomorrow. I wrote to Mrs. Alexander.

I am giving a course of historical lectures to troops.
Entry.101:
Very hot today.

Spent 2 nights & one day at Sierra Leone (Freetown) and coaled from lighters, the natives handling the coal.

I bought a work basket & gum bangles here. A third died & was buried at sea between Sierra Leone & Capetown. Reached Capetownon
Entry.102: May at 4 pm & remained there until 4pm on
Entry.103: We all had a very interesting time here and were well treated by the people.
Entry.104:
I visited Mr. Adrian Van der Ryl and went home with him to Kenilworth to dinner. During the day I was on picquet duty. Bought ostrich feathers, set of furs, beads, boa, aigrette 
of
 osprey & books. Went to TivoliTheatre.
Entry.105: Visited Simonstown, Kalk Bay, Muizenburg & Wynberg. Went in surf at Muizenburg. Had dinner & game of billiards at Wynberg Hotel.
Entry.106:
Visited City, Parliament House, & Cecil Rhodes' Home. Had a

pleasant motor drive to Rhodes House & back to boat.
Entry.107: After a pleasant voyage - but uneventful - we reached Fremantle on
Entry.108:
berthing about 5.30 pm. Having leave until 11 pm I visited Perth & sent telegram to Jess. Bought fruit, lollies, cakes and shaving gear.

Left Fremantle this morning.
